div3.head: Partisan Rangers.--
div3.p:
My Battalion of Mountel Rangers will be ready to take the field in two weeks. Only one more company required.
Those wishing to unite will please address me immediately.
Lt-Col. W. G. Claiborne,

All members of the Pamunkey.
Artillery now absent, are ordered to rejoin their Company at once, at Warwick's Bend, on James River.
div3.closer:
B. T. Ellett,
Captain Company. my 10--5t*

div3.head: Runaways
div3.p:
--$20 reward — On Monday morning last, four negromen, to with John H Pkins; Willia Jones, Bob Lomax and page Lomax, were start from the farm of Mr. James M Taylor, about five miles below the city, for my office, and have felled to report to me. They are owned by Mr. N Quesenberry, of King George county.
They are all young, and of low statute William has a yellow skin, and the others a dark gingerbread color.
A further description is not recolected . The above reward will be paid for them, or five dollars for either of them, if delivered to sir. Ro.
Lumpkins's jail in this city.
div3.closer:
Thos. J Bagby, General Agent,
No. 8 Wall street. my 10--1t

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Runaway from the subscriber, near Dyton, M. Ringo county, Ala., my dining-room servant, James, sometimes caring himself James Clarke, a bright mulatto, about twenty-five years of age, slightly bowlegged; was raised in Richmond, Va., by a Dr. Totty.
His parents still live there.--James was in the army last summer at Winchester.
A reasonable reward will be paid for his apprehension and confinement in jail so that I get him again.

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p: --$10 reward — I win pay the above reward for the apprehension and delivery to me of a mulatto boy named William sometimes called Ben. He is about 16 years old; full-head of hair; about 5 fee high; stout and wel He has been raised to waiting in the house and was like to Mrs Jo B oa st when he left, he belongs to Mr. Jas. C. Ray, of Henrico so.

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 113, page 4.

div4.head: Mr. Russell Thinks of going to the scene of operations.
div4.p:
The expeditionary force is nearly all embarked and concentrated at Fortress Monroe, or on the mainland between the James and York rivers.
Before this letter leaves Boston, it is probable that I shall have reached the scene of operations, embarking either here or at Alexandria or Washington, as the case may be, with my companions.
The General commanding, and the staff, have not yet gone on board the steamers detailed for their use, but the almost is done to get stores and all the vast variety of materials connected with such an army and such an expedition in readiness, and no doubt this week will witness remarkable events around Fortress Monroe.

div4.head: His opinion of Island no.10 and New Orleans.
div4.p:
From Island No.10 comes an admission of failure, though the bombardment was renewed on the 29th.
But it is hoped that, as soon as the river falls, the Federal troops will be able to advance, and thus clear the river; and the news of a successful attack on New Orleans is confidently expected, after which the Unionists consider the Mississippi virtually in their hands, not with standing the fortifications above Memphis, and the immense levies at Corinth and other places near its shore — New Orleans, however, may prove as formidable as Island No.10.

div4.head: The American Press and Mr. Stanton.
div4.p:
In one of Wilson's or Anderson's ornithological papers there is an account of the wonder and fierceness of a certain sort of American woodpecker when it was first put in a cage.--All the present actions and behavior of the American Press are described to the life in it. At last it began to tear cut its own feathers.
Here is Mr. Stanton--the man of an hour, the lawyer of yesterday; the hippodromes, the press-tamer of to-day!--How he has grown, almost in a moment, into life and power ! So did Denton, so did Ponche, so did Robespierre.
But, remember, they had no such cause as "the Union." If they thought they had, they were no doubt wrong.
If any one desires to read the finest, purest, most bright flown works they were ever uttered about liberty, purity and morality, let him turn to the pages of the French Republican journals in the time of the worship of the gadders Reason.
Let no one suppose the writers were not sincere, though the lady who sat in the car might have in the flash undergone the ordeals of the correctional police.
Let none suppose that "the Union" now does not fire the Northern heart, and move the souls of those great masses which have lain so long beneath the weight of dollar bags, from the Canadian lakes to the Susquehanna and the Ohio, today with a fresh current of thought and feeling; a new arterial system of hope and action has been put into them.
One of the great triumphs of their young career is that they have slain the mother that fostered and bore them; which had, however, become a stepmother and tyrannized them to death.
There is no one in Congress, there is not in Senate, in House of Representatives, in pulpit, or stump, or in the forum, a man who has a word to say in this year of grace, 1862, against a war on the press compared, with which there has been nothing known even in the days of Andrew Marvel.
The almost the boldest journals venture upon is to give warning to their agents to flee from some doubtful wrath to come.
And the American people are very glad of it; leastways, they don't appear at all dissatisfied.
Here are billiard-table keepers and whiskey-drinkers getting up public meetings, and all sorts of interests moving against taxation, but not a man cries out "murder," or even "robbery, " far less a "fire," at the visible institution of all life in the press in its function of giving news.
Devotion to the Union cannot do much more.
When an American is content to do without news in his newspaper, he has exhausted submission and forbearance and made his sacrifice.

div4.head: Mr. Russell will write from Fortress Monroe, Etc.
div4.p:
My next letter will be from the neighborhood of Fortress Monroe.
The Rinaldo is still lying off Old Point Comfort, and two French vessels, one the Colinat, have hurried up to enjoy the spectacle of a renewed encounter between the knights in armor.
The Raser is off Charleston, whence comes the rumor of another arrival of arms and munitions, in a steamer which ran the blockade.
There is no news yet from the ide and the shipowner are by no means happy in their mines.
In the forthcoming encounter, one of the opponents of the Merrimac intends to try large shells upon her. The Navy Department has given orders for the manufacture of a number of flat-headed bolts, on Whitworth's plan, to pierce the iron plates, if possible.
In reference to this matter.
I may observe that an erroneous impression, for which I am in some degree responsible, appears to have been created in Europe that Capt., Dahlgren is of opinion that shell could be used with effect against armored ships.
His theory is that iron shot of a low velocity will prove most destructive, and serve the problem of meeting such antagonists, when guns have been constructed of adequate calibres.
The Government of the United States is quite alive to the importance of this question, and their officers are not at all likely to treat it unskillfully or inefficiently.
Even Congress begins to push forward the work, and readily votes money for the construction of an iron fleet, although Stevens's great ram is not altogether approved is a medium of expenditure.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, from John Quarter's brickyard, in the city of Richmond, where he was hired for the present year, on or about the 15th of April, a negro boy, named Hunphesy.
He is about 20 years old, well built, quite dark and full featured, with a small scar on one of his checks; no other scar or mark recollected.
He generally looks down when spoken to. The last time he was seen he was on the York River cars, supposed to be on his way to Yorktown or some other place on the peninsula.
He may have passed himself off as a free negro and hired himself to some company, as a good many soldiers were on the cars the day he was seen on them.
The above reward will be paid if delivered to Miles C. Eggleston, in the city of Richmond, or to me, in the county of Hanover, near Old Church Post-Office.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my saw mill, in Buckingham county, on Monday, May 5th, 1862, my negro man, named Jorn.
Said negro is about 22 years old, singer-bread color, quite stout, and wide across the shoulders, and about 5 feet 4 or 5 inches high, and usually wears a cap. I bought John in March last, at the auction room of Dickinson & Hill, in Richmond, of Mr. George Turner, of Prince William county, Va., where he has a wife, and may endeavor to get back.
The above reward will be paid upon his delivery to my overseer, Mr. Payne, or to myself, in Richmond.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway, on yesterday morning, my negro man, Frank Cheatham, about 35 years old. He has a down look, rather stammering when spoken to. Said negro is a stout, square built man, dark brown color, about 5 feet 6 inches high; had on when last seen a dark colored army overcoat.
He was last seen in Rocketts Old Field, supposed to be making his way to the enemy's lines.
I will give the above reward if delivered to me, or to Thos. W. Keesee, corner of 12th and Cary streets, or lodged in any jail so that I can get him again.

div3.head: $50 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, on Wednesday last, a negro boy named William, lately purchased of Mr. David Lyon, of Petersburg.
William is about 21 years of age, 5 feet 8½ inches high, black complexion, two false teeth set on gold plate, wore when he left a soldier's shirt, and is a bricklayer by trade.
I will give the above reward for his delivery to me in Richmond, Va., or for his confinement in jail so that I get him again.

div3.head: $25 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the residence of Dr. F. W. Hancock, a tall, young, and likely mulatto woman, named Rose, about 22 years old. She was hired a part of last year to Col. Weston.
I will give the above reward for her apprehension and delivery to me in Richmond, or put in some jail so I can get her.

div3.head: Ranaway--$10 reward.
div3.p:
--On Friday, 28th of March, my girl Jane.
She is 14 years of age, dark, well grown, tall and stout, flat nose and forehead; the forefinger of the right hand is off up to the first joint, occasioned by a whitlow.
I think she is in Richmond with her mother.
The above reward will be paid if secured in jail so that I can get her, or to E. D. Eacho.

div3.head: $20 reward.
div3.p:
--On Thursday, the 24th of April, my negro man, George, left my farm, in Powhatan county.
Said negro is thirty years of age, bright mulatto, and about five feet nine or ten inches high.
I will give the above reward if delivered to me, or $10 for any information that will lead to his recovery.
Mrs. E. M. Moseley.
Powhatan co., May 7, 1862.

div3.head: $10 reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from my house, on the 5th inst., my negro boy, Joe. He is 5 feet 4 inches high, ginger-bread color, and a butcher by trade.
I will give the above reward for his delivery to me, at my house, or my stall at the Old Market.

div3.head: Scott's Partisan Rangers.
div3.p:
Having been authorized by Major Scott to raise a company, as part of his corps of Partisan Rangers, to be supplied with Williams's breach loading mounted lifts, I am prepared to receive any and all effective men not now in service; and I appeal especially to exiles from Kentucky, Maryland, and Northwestern Virginia.--Our commander was Captain of the celebrated Black Horse Cavalry, that proved so destructive to the invaders at Bull Run and Manassas.
He will land us into the very heart of the enemy's country, and enable us to strike terror to the minions of the miserable tyrant who has dared to wage a merc s was upon the young Confederacy of the South.
Let there be no lack of heroic men to follow him.

The gun with which this company will be armed be most wonderful and destructive weapon of the age. It can be loaded and fired from 20 to 3 per minute, and will shoot with precision from three-fourths of a mile to a mile, when loaded with ball, and when loaded with buck-shot or market halls, it will scatter death had destruction in the face of the for at the distance of from three to five hundred yards indeed, it may be confidently affirmed that one company, armed with this weapon, will do more fearful execution than a whole regiment supplied with ordinary infantry arms.
Besides promising to be the most effective arm of the public service, the members of this corps will be entitled, in addition to the pay of regular soldiers, to compensation for all the arms and munitions of war captured from the enemy.
Persons desirous to engage in this most desirable and attractive branch of warfare, will please apply at once to the undersigned, Bank street, near 12th, Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Persons wishing to join the Secret service for the war, will have the privilege of doing so by calling at my office, over the counting room of Messrs. McKinney & Dupuy, Shockoe Slip, near Columbian Hotel.
Office will be open from the 12th inst.

div3.head: Otey battery.
div3.p: Wanted, ten more good men for this company, Persons desiring to connect themselves with this fine company can do so by early application at the Insurance Company, opposite the American Hotel, to

div3.head: Headq'rs Letcher, Artillery. May 7, 1862.
div3.p: One hundred dollars reward ! Deserted from my company, at present stationed in the vicinity of Massaponax Church, near Fredericksburg, the following men, for the delivery of whom to me at the above post, or to Capt. Alexander at the Provost prison in Richmond, one hundred dollars reward for each will be paid, viz: Austin N. Denpsey, Samuel H. Mosies, and Eugene R. Grinnan.
A. N. Dempsey is 22 years of age, 5 feet 4 inches high, has dark hair, hazel eyes, fair, ruddy complexion, and was born in Baltimore.
Samuel H. Mosier is 22 years of age, 6 feet 8½ inches high, light, brown hair, light, bluish eyes, full face, sallow complexion, well built, and hairs from Louisiana.
Eugene R. Grinnan is 21 years of age, about 5 feet 9 inches high, has dark, brown hair, gray eyes, and fair complexion — hails from Georgia.
And I hereby forewarn all persons from harboring, or in any manner aiding, the above deserters, as the law will be rigidly enforced against all so offending.
div3.closer:
Greenlee Davidson,
Captain Letcher Light Artillery,
3d Brigade, Army of the Rappahannock. my 8--1w

div3.head:
[extract]
Headq's Department of Henrico,
Richmond, Va., May 7, 1862.
div3.p: Special Orders, No. 79

II.
By direction of General Lee, all officers now in Richmond belonging to troops serving on the Peninsula, will report immediately for duty at these Headquarters.
Soldiers returning to duty will report to the Commanding Officer at Camp Winder.
div3.closer:
By order of Brig. Gen. John H. Winder.
L. R. Page, A. A. Gen. my 8--6t

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond Va., March 11, 1862.

II.
Railroad companies are forbidden to transport into this city or out of it, spirituous liquors or other intoxicating beverages.

III.

By order of
Brig. Gen'l Jno. H. Winder, Com. &c.
L. R. Page, A. A. Gen'l. mb 13--ts

div3.head: Attention, Marylanders !
div3.p: The following copy of a letter from Hon. Geo. W. Randolph. Secretary of War, a t at rest all doubts as the position of Marylanders under the Conscription Act:

div4.head:
[copy.]
Confederate States of America, War Department,
Richmond May 1, 1862.
div4.opener:
Capt. R. C. smith, Co. "C," 1st Maryland Reg't, Care major J. A. Weston, Richmond, Va:
Sir:
div4.p: In reply to your letter of the 23d ult., you are respectfully informed that the Maryland companies are not subject to conscription, and will go out of service when their term of enlistment expires.
div4.closer:
Your obedient servant.
[Signed] Geo. W. Randolph,
Secretary of War.

div4.p: This applies to all Marylanders, as shown by the following extract from another letter from the Secretary of War, dated April 26th.
"Major J. A. Weston:
"In reply to your letter of the 17th inst., you are respectfully informed that Marylanders are not subject to the Conscription Act.

By this decision all twelve months' Marylanders who have been re- enlisted under compulsion, are entitled to their discharge or transfer, and all who have re-enlisted voluntarily have still the privilege of electing the company or regiment which they will join.
my 5--6t*

div3.head:
Second Company
Johnson's Light
Artillery.
div3.p:
More recruits are wanted for this company forthwith.
The conscription will soon be passed, mustering into the service every man in the Confederacy between the ages of 18 and 35, leaving no option with the conscript as to where he shall go, or to what arm of the service he shall belong.

All those who prefer to select the Light Artillery as their service should take at once the last opportunity they will probably have to volunteer.
We desire, at the earliest possible moment, to complete our organization and take the field, where all who are fit for service should be, and where they must be soon, either voluntarily or by compulsion.

Those who have been in service know that the Light Artillery is the most agreeable us well as the most effective arm of the service.
Come at once, then, while the chance is given you to enlist where you please, and relieve yourselves from the opprobrium of compulsory service.
Recruiting Office, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig Building.

div3.head:
Headquarters Ordnance Departm't,
Richmond, Va., March 28th, 1862.
div3.p:
This Department is Desirous of purchasing arms from those parties having good double-barrel shot guns, sporting rifles, or any kind of weapons that will be useful in the field.
There arms will be fairly appraised on their delivery in Richmond, and payments will be promptly made.
Agents heretofore collecting State arms for this Department are requested to collect and forward these private arms as promptly as possible.
div3.closer:
G. Dimmock,
Col. of Ordnance of Virginia. mh 29--tf

div3.head: Maryland Battalion.
div3.p: The undersigned has been authorized to organize a Battalion of Infantry, to form part of the Maryland Line.

Under an act of Congress, approved February 15, 1862, any native or adopted citizen of Maryland may, upon his own application, be transferred at once to the Maryland Line.
Or any company composed of citizens of Maryland or the District of Columbia may, upon application, be so transferred.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining this Battalion, will apply in person at the office of Weston & Williams, No. 15 Pearl street, or by mall to
div3.closer:
J. A. Weston,
Richmond Va. mh 13--ts

div3.head: Attention, Volunteers.--Infantry Company--Scott's Battalion.
div3.p:
--Under authority from the Secretary of War, the undersigned--two of whom are graduates of the Virginia Military Institute--are forming an Infantry Company for the battalion now being raised by Robert G. Scott, who served as Captain of Virginia volunteers in the Mexican war. Men liable to service under the conscript act can volunteer in this company and receive the bounty, &c., instead of being enrolled as, conscripts, as they soon will be, to fill up companies now in service, without receiving any bounty.
Men in companies for local service wishing to go into active service may also join the company.
Recruiting office 10th street, between Main and Bank.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--Capt. Wm. W. Parker's Company of Light Artillery having been mustered into service, and secured a battery of six guns, are now in the camp of instruction, and will receive a few more Recruits, if they are of the right sort.
Apply at his office, in the Law Building, at once.

div3.head: Partisan Rangers.
div3.p: --I have received the requisite authority to entitle a corps of Partisan Rangers to serve during the war.

The corps is designed to consist of Mounted Riflemen, Cavalry, and infantry, and have attached to it a company armed with the light howitzer.
I propose to operate within the enemy's lines, and will be enabled to hold out the prospect of a more active life than that which falls to the lot of the regular soldier; at all events, the members of the corps will not be subjected to the tedium of camp life.

I cordially and most earnestly invite all who desire to enter the Partisan branch of the service to unite with me, and all companies and battalions not mustered into the Confederate service.
I desire gentlemen who propose to unite with me to bring with them such private arms as they may be able to command — shot guns, rifles, pistols, &c.

The wolf is hunted for his scalp, and our Government has determined to pay for all arms and munitions of war which we may capture from the enemy; thus placing the invaders of our country and the oppressors of our liberty upon the footing of the savage beasts of the forest, to be captured or slain at all times and by any means not prohibited by legal warfare.

I invoke all enterprising men to join me, who are not engaged in the military service, and especially those whose homes are in the possession of the enemy — I invoke them to join me whether animated by a simple love of country, or a hatred of the public enemy; whether they have a wrong to redress, a vengeance to slake, or a home to protect.
Gentlemen wishing to raise companies for the corps will address me at Richmond city, Va., or apply in peace at my recruiting rendezvous, in this city, at the Palmetto House, corner 12th and Main st.
div3.closer:
John Scott,
Of Fauquier, Capt. C. S. A. my 7--ts

div3.head:
War Department, Adj't and Insp. Gen.'s office,
Richmond, May 3d, 1862.
div3.p: General Orders--No. 34.
I. The following proclamation is published for the information of all concerned:

div4.head: Proclamation.
div4.p: By virtue of the power vested in me by law to declare the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus:

I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States of America, do proclaim that martial law is hereby extended over the counties of Lee, Wise, Buchanan, McDowell, and Wyoming, under the command of Brigadier-General Humphrey Marshall; and I do proclaim the suspension of all civil jurisdiction, (with the exception of that enabling the Courts to take cognizance of the probate of wills, the administration of the estates of deceased persons, the qualification of guardians, to enter decrees and orders for the partition and sale of property, to make orders concerning roads and bridges, to assess county levies, and to order the payment of county dues,) and the suspension of the write of habeas corpus in the counties aforeiaid.
In faith whereof I have hereunto signed my name, and set my seal this the 3d day of May, in the year one thousand eight hundred and sixty-two.

II. Brigadier-General Humphrey Marshall is charged with the due execution of the foregoing proclamation.
He will forthwith establish an efficient military police, and will enforce the following orders:

q.p:
All distillation of spirituous liquors is positively prohibited, and the distilleries will forth with be closed.
The sale of spirituous liquors of any kind is also prohibited, and establishments for the sale thereof will be closed.

div4.p:
III.
All persons infringing the above prohibitions will suffer such punishment as shall be ordered by the sentence of a Court-Martial; provided, that no sentence to hard labor for more than one month shall be inflicted by the sentence of a regimental Court-Martial, as directed by the 67th article of war.
div4.closer:
By command of the Secretary of War.
S. Cooper,
Adj't and Insp. Gen'l. my 5--6t

div3.head: Military, attention.
div3.p:
The undersigned are manufacturing and have for sale Brass Pressed Letters, Cross Cannons, Cross Sabres, &c., for Military Caps, and wish to call the attention of the military to the fact.
Orders promptly attended to
div3.closer:
Kayton & Snead,
Letter Cutters,
13th, between Main and Cary sts.
Address, by mail, Kayton & Snead, Box 995, Richmond, Va. my 8--12t*

div3.head: Attention, Light Artillery.
div3.p:
--I am authorized by the Governor to receive Substitutes in my company of Light Artillery, and to muster them in as they come.
Those, therefore, who desire to procure substitutes, or who wish to become substitutes, should call at once at my headquarters, Johnson & Guigon's office, under the Whig ding.
div3.closer:
A. B. Guigon,
Captain Light Artillery. mh 28--

div3.head: Attention, Martin's battery !
div3.p: --All members of this command who are absent without leave, will report at once at "Camp Lee," or they will be reported to the Provost Guard and arrested as deserters.
Persons wishing to join the company will apply to Serg't Pulliam, at the Recruiting office, corner of Bank and 12th streets.
